Continuous Processes¶

The stochastic.continuous module provides classes for generating (discretely sampled) continous stochastic processes.

  • stochastic.continuous.BesselProcess
  • stochastic.continuous.BrownianBridge
  • stochastic.continuous.BrownianExcursion
  • stochastic.continuous.BrownianMeander
  • stochastic.continuous.BrownianMotion
  • stochastic.continuous.CauchyProcess
  • stochastic.continuous.FractionalBrownianMotion
  • stochastic.continuous.GammaProcess
  • stochastic.continuous.GeometricBrownianMotion
  • stochastic.continuous.Poisson
  • stochastic.continuous.SquaredBesselProcess
  • stochastic.continuous.VarianceGammaProcess
  • stochastic.continuous.WienerProcess
class stochastic.continuous.BesselProcess(t=1, dim=1)[source]¶

Bessel process.

Generate Bessel process realizations using dim independent Brownian motion processes on the interval \([0,t]\)

Parameters:
  • t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
  • dim (int) – the number of underlying independent Brownian motions to use
sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of a Bessel process.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
t¶

Time end.

times(n, zero=True)¶

Generate times associated with n increments on [0, t].

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
class stochastic.continuous.BrownianBridge(t=1, b=0)[source]¶

Brownian bridge.

A Brownian bridge is a Brownian motion with a conditional value on the right endpoint of the process.

Parameters:
  • t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
  • b (float) – the right endpoint value of the Brownian bridge at time t
b¶

The right endpoint value.

sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of a Brownian bridge.

Generate realizations of a Brownian bridge in which the value at time \(t\) is equal to \(b\).

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate
  • zero (bool) – if True, include time \(t=0\)

class stochastic.continuous.BrownianExcursion(t=1)[source]¶

Brownian excursion.

A Brownian excursion is a Brownian bridge from (0, 0) to (t, 0) which is conditioned to be nonnegative on the interval [0, 1].

Parameters:t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a Brownian excursion.

class stochastic.continuous.BrownianMeander(t=1)[source]¶

Brownian meander process.

A Brownian motion conditioned such that the process is nonnegative.

Parameters:t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
sample(n, b=None, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a Brownian meander realization.

Generage a Brownian meander using the Williams, 1970 / Imhof, 1984 algorithm.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate
  • b (float) – the nonnegative right hand endpoint of the meander
  • zero (bool) – if True, include time \(t=0\)

class stochastic.continuous.BrownianMotion(t=1, drift=0, scale=1)[source]¶

Brownian motion.

A standard Brownian motion (discretely sampled) has independent and identically distributed Gaussian increments with variance equal to increment length. Non-standard Brownian motion includes a linear drift parameter and scale factor.

Parameters:
  • t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
  • drift (float) – rate of change of the expected value
  • scale (float) – scale factor of the Gaussian process
drift¶

Drift parameter.

sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of Brownian Motion.

Generate a Brownian motion realization with drift and scale.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
sample_at(times, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a Brownian motion at specified times.

Parameters:
  • times – a vector of increasing time values at which to generate the Brownian motion
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
scale¶

Scale parameter.

Time end.

class stochastic.continuous.CauchyProcess(t=1)[source]¶

Symmetric Cauchy process.

The symmetric Cauchy process is a Brownian motion with a Levy subordinator using location parameter 0 and scale parameter \(t^2/2\).

Parameters:t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of a Cauchy process.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate.
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)

Time end.

Generate times associated with n increments on [0, t].

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
class stochastic.continuous.FractionalBrownianMotion(t=1, hurst=0.5)[source]¶

Fractional Brownian motion process.

A fractional Brownian motion (discretely sampled) has correlated Gaussian increments defined by Hurst parameter H. When H == 1/2, the process is a standard Brownian motion. When H > 1/2, the increments are positively correlated. When H < 1/2, the increments are negatively correlated.

Parameters:
  • t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
  • hurst (float) – the Hurst parameter on the interval (0, 1)
hurst¶

Hurst parameter.

sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of fractional Brownian motion.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
t¶

Time end.

times(n, zero=True)¶

Generate times associated with n increments on [0, t].

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
class stochastic.continuous.GammaProcess(t=1, mean=None, variance=None, rate=None, scale=None)[source]¶

Gamma process.

A Gamma process (discretely sampled) is the summation of stationary independent increments which are distributed as gamma random variables. This class supports instantiation using the mean/variance parametrization or the rate/scale parametrization.

Parameters:
  • t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
  • mean (float) – mean increase per unit time; supply with variance
  • variance (float) – variance of increase per unit time; supply with mean
  • rate (float) – the rate of jump arrivals; supply with scale
  • scale (float) – the size of the jumps; supple with rate
mean¶

Mean increase per unit time.

rate¶

Rate of jump arrivals.

sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of a Gamma process.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
sample_at(times)[source]¶

Generate a realization of a Gamma process at specified times.

Parameters:times (int) – the number of increments to generate
scale¶

Scale parameter for jump sizes.

t¶

Time end.

times(n, zero=True)¶

Generate times associated with n increments on [0, t].

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
variance¶

Variance of increase per unit time.

class stochastic.continuous.GeometricBrownianMotion(t=1, drift=0, volatility=1)[source]¶

Geometric Brownian motion process.

A geometric Brownian motion \(S_t\) is the analytic solution to the stochastic differential equation with Wiener process \(W_t\):

\[dS_t = \mu S_t dt + \sigma S_t dW_t\]

and can be represented with initial value \(S_0\) in the form:

\[S_t = S_0 \exp \left( \left( \mu - \frac{\sigma^2}{2} \right) t + \sigma W_t \right)\]
Parameters:
  • t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
  • drift (float) – the parameter \(\mu\)
  • volatility (float) – the parameter \(\sigma\)
drift¶

Geometric Brownian motion drift parameter.

sample(n, initial=1, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of geometric Brownian motion.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate.
  • initial (float) – the initial value of the process \(S_0\).
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
t¶

Time end.

times(n, zero=True)¶

Generate times associated with n increments on [0, t].

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
volatility¶

Geometric Brownian motion volatility parameter.

class stochastic.continuous.PoissonProcess(rate=1)[source]¶

Poisson process.

A Poisson process with rate \(\lambda\) is a count of occurrences of i.i.d. exponential random variables with mean \(1/\lambda\). This class generates samples of times for which cumulative exponential random variables occur.

Parameters:rate (float) – the parameter \(\lambda\) which defines the rate of occurrences of the process
rate¶

Rate parameter.

sample(n=None, length=None)[source]¶

Generate a realization of a Poisson process.

Exactly one of the following parameters must be provided.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of arrivals to simulate
  • length (int) – the length of time to simulate; will generate arrivals until length is met or exceeded.
class stochastic.continuous.SquaredBesselProcess(t=1, dim=1)[source]¶

The square of a Bessel process.

Parameters:

  • dim (int) – the number of underlying independent Brownian motions to use
dim¶

Dimensions, or independent Brownian motions.

  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)

class stochastic.continuous.VarianceGammaProcess(t=1, drift=0, variance=1, scale=1)[source]¶

Variance Gamma process.

A variance gamma process has independent increments which follow the variance-gamma distribution. It can be represented as a Brownian motion with drift subordinated by a Gamma process:

\[\theta \Gamma(t; 1, \nu) + \sigma W(\Gamma(t; 1, \nu))\]
Parameters:
  • t (float) – the right hand endpoint of the time interval \([0,t]\) for the process
  • drift (float) – the drift parameter of the Brownian motion, or \(\theta\) above
  • variance (float) – the variance parameter of the Gamma subordinator, or \(\nu\) above
  • scale (float) – the scale parameter of the Brownian motion, or \(\sigma\) above
drift¶

Drift parameter.

sample(n, zero=True)[source]¶

Generate a realization of a variance gamma process.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – the number of increments to generate
  • zero (bool) – if True, include \(t=0\)
scale¶

Scale parameter.

t¶

Time end.

variance¶

Variance parameter.
